abstract.text: An object that manages the display of content in a popover.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: From the time a popover is presented until the time it’s dismissed, UIKit uses an instance of this class to manage the presentation behavior. You use instances of this class as-is to configure aspects of the popover appearance and behavior for view controllers whose presentation style is set to
In nearly all cases, you use this class as-is and don’t create instances of it directly. UIKit creates an instance of this class automatically when you present a view controller using the
style. You can retrieve that instance from the presented view controller’s
property and use it to configure the popover behavior.

If you don’t want to configure a popover immediately after presenting a view controller, you can use a delegate object to configure the popover instead. During the presentation process, the popover presentation controller calls various methods of its delegate—an object that conforms to the

protocol—to ask for information and to inform it about the state of the presentation. Your delegate object can use those methods to configure the popover and adjust its behavior as needed. For information about how to implement a delegate for a popover presentation controller, see
For information about how to display a view controller using a popover presentation controller, see

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
A presentation style where the content is displayed in a popover view.
The background appearance for a popover.
A set of methods that popover background view subclasses must implement.
An object that manages the display of content in a popover.
The sheet presentation controller the popover adapts to in compact size classes.
The arrow direction in use by the popover.
The color of the popover’s backdrop view.
The bar button item on which to anchor the popover.
A Boolean value indicating whether the popover can overlap its view rectangle.
The delegate that handles popover-related messages.
An array of views that the user can interact with while the popover is visible.
The arrow directions that you allow for the popover.
The class to use for displaying the popover background content.
The margins that define the portion of the screen in which it is permissible to display the popover.
The item on which to anchor the popover.
The area in the source view in which you anchor the popover.
The view containing the anchor rectangle for the popover.
The interface for a popover presentation delegate, which lets you customize the behavior of a popover-based presentation.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
An object that manages the transition animations and the presentation of view controllers onscreen.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The nearest popover presentation controller that is managing the current view controller.
Show a temporary interface on top of your app’s content on iPad.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Displaying transient content in a popover

abstract.text: The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
